awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Commercialization of advanced bipolar membranes for applications in water treatment, carbon-dioxide capture and utilization, and environmental remediation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to improve existing industrial processes using bipolar membranes (BPMs), such as the production of acid and base for water treatment, and enable new ones, such as capturing carbon dioxide from the ocean and air and using it to form fuels and chemicals. The global market revenue expected to increase from $90 M to $240 M by 2027, with greater growth possible if BPMs are used in emerging carbon dioxide capture and utilization applications. This project will enable commercial BPM processes to durably operate 10x faster than existing processes, therefore dramatically lowering cost. 

The proposed project will address key challenges to: (1) develop adhesive processes that maintain or improve upon the electrochemical performance in current small-scale research BPMs made without adhesive, which is essential for applications and long-term durability; (2) characterize and optimize the BPM ion selectivity and demonstrate improved performance in commercially relevant electrodialysis systems, (3) develop and use accelerated stress tests to forecast end-of-life electrodialysis performance for optimized BPMs and compare the performance and lifetimes to current commercial BPMs, while mitigating the identified degradation modes to implement designs that yield a lifetime of a minimum of two years, and (4) develop a scalable roll-to-roll process for scalable BPM fabrication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on advancing bipolar membrane (BPM) technology to make it more efficient, durable, and ready for large-scale production. BPMs are special components used in electrochemical devices that help enable advanced energy and materials-refining technologies.

One breakthrough was developing a new method to manufacture BPMs that can be easily scaled up for industrial use. We created a one-step process to produce advanced catalysts made from tin oxide (SnO2) directly on BPMs. These catalysts help split water with record-low energy use and remain stable for long periods, making them ideal for real-world applications. We successfully scaled up this process to a 100 cm2 membrane, proving its potential for production. The research led to the launch of a startup dedicated to bringing next-generation BPMs to market. This new company is initially focusing on carbon capture, peroxide production, and wastewater treatment—areas where BPM technology can have a major commerial impact. 

Beyond technical advances, this project has helped train researchers who have gone on to work in academia and industry. The project provided hands-on learning opportunities for students through the Electrochemical Technology M.S. Professional Program at the University of Oregon. The advanced BPM technology developed in part by this program is now being used in research and development in industry and academic laboratories around the world. Our findings have been published in top scientific journals, patented, and presented at major conferences.


Last Modified: 02/18/2025
Modified by: Shannon W Boettcher
